title: Kernel panic when enabling packet capture on high-traffic interfaces
content:
System experiences kernel panic when attempting to enable packet capture on 40Gbps interfaces with sustained traffic >30Gbps.

## Environment
- PlexNet Version: 2.3.1
- OS: Ubuntu Server 22.04.3 LTS (Kernel 5.15.0-89-generic)
- Hardware: Dell PowerEdge R750 (Intel Xeon Gold 6338, 256GB RAM)
- Network Interfaces: Mellanox ConnectX-6 100Gbps (4 ports)
- Traffic Load: 35-45 Gbps sustained

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Configure packet capture on interface `ens1f0` (40Gbps link)
2. Set capture filter: `tcp port 443`
3. Start capture with buffer size 1GB
4. System becomes unresponsive within 30-60 seconds
5. Kernel panic: `BUG: unable to handle kernel paging request at ffffffffc0000000`

## Expected Behavior
Packet capture should work without system instability, even on high-speed interfaces.

## Actual Behavior
System crashes with kernel panic. Capture works fine on 1Gbps and 10Gbps interfaces.

## Logs
```
[  234.567890] PlexNet Capture: Starting packet capture on ens1f0
[  245.123456] kernel: [Hardware Error]: Machine check events logged
[  256.789012] Kernel panic - not syncing: Fatal exception in interrupt
[  256.789013] CPU: 12 PID: 0 Comm: swapper/12 Tainted: G           OE     5.15.0-89-generic
```

## Workaround
None available. Have to avoid packet capture on high-speed interfaces.

## Impact
Critical - Prevents network troubleshooting on backbone links. Affects production network monitoring capabilities.

## Attachments
- `kernel_panic_log.txt`
- `system_info.json`
- `interface_config.yaml`
- `capture_settings.conf`

title: Memory leak in SNMP poller causes gradual performance degradation
content:
SNMP poller process exhibits memory leak, causing gradual performance degradation over time. Memory usage increases by approximately 50MB per hour under normal load.

## Environment
- PlexNet Version: 2.3.0
- OS: CentOS 7.9.2009
- Hardware: VMware VM (8 vCPU, 16GB RAM)
- SNMP Devices: 450 Cisco switches and routers
- Polling Interval: 60 seconds

## Symptoms
- Memory usage starts at ~2GB, grows to 8GB+ over 24 hours
- SNMP polling response time increases from 0.5s to 5s+
- System becomes unresponsive, requires restart
- No memory is freed during garbage collection cycles

## Investigation
Using `valgrind` and heap profiling, identified memory leak in SNMP session management:
- SNMP session objects not being properly closed
- OID cache growing indefinitely
- Prepared statements accumulating in connection pool

## Code Location
Issue appears to be in `/src/snmp/poller.go` around line 234:
```go
session, err := snmp.NewSession(target)
// session.Close() not called in error paths
```

## Impact
High - Requires daily service restarts in production environment. Affects monitoring reliability for enterprise network with 450 devices.

## Temporary Fix
Restart PlexNet service daily at 2 AM to prevent memory exhaustion.

## Requested Fix
Implement proper SNMP session cleanup and add connection pool limits.
author: Systems Administrator

title: SSL certificate validation bypass in webhook delivery
content:
Webhook delivery system does not properly validate SSL certificates, allowing man-in-the-middle attacks when delivering alerts to HTTPS endpoints.

## Security Impact
- **CVSS Score**: 7.4 (High)
- **Attack Vector**: Network
- **Confidentiality Impact**: High
- **Integrity Impact**: High

## Vulnerability Details
The webhook client uses an HTTP client that disables SSL certificate verification:
```go
tr := &http.Transport{
    TLSClientConfig: &tls.Config{InsecureSkipVerify: true},
}
```

This affects all webhook deliveries to HTTPS URLs, potentially allowing attackers to:
1. Intercept alert notifications
2. Modify alert contents
3. Redirect alerts to malicious endpoints

## Affected Components
- Webhook delivery service
- Alert notification system
- Integration endpoints (Slack, Teams, custom HTTPS webhooks)

## Reproduction
1. Set up webhook endpoint with self-signed certificate
2. Configure PlexNet to send alerts to this endpoint
3. Use mitmproxy or similar tool to intercept traffic
4. Observe that SSL certificate validation is bypassed

## Remediation
- Remove `InsecureSkipVerify: true` from TLS configuration
- Implement proper certificate validation
- Add option for custom CA certificates
- Add certificate pinning for known endpoints

## Timeline
- Vulnerability discovered: 2024-11-15
- Reported to vendor: 2024-11-20
- Vendor acknowledged: 2024-11-25
- Fix expected: TBD

## Impact
All customers using HTTPS webhooks are affected. Enterprise customers with sensitive network alerts should disable webhook functionality until patched.
author: Security Researcher
